Project  The road sections to be improved under the Project are an integral part 
Description  of a regional road network in Central Asia that directly links Kazakhstan, 
the Kyrgyz Republic, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), Tajikistan, 
Afghanistan, and Uzbekistan. More broadly, this network is part of a 
larger network providing links to the ocean ports of Iran and Pakistan to 
the south, and to the Russian Federation to the north. The project road 
links the Rasht Valley in Tajikistan and the capital, Dushanbe. Poverty 
incidence in the project area, estimated at 68%, is higher than the 
national  poverty  incidence  of  64%.  The  project  outputs  include  (i) 
improvement of 89 kilometers (km) of the central and border sections of 
the  Dushanbe–Kyrgyz  border  road  and  60  km  of  rural  roads;  (ii) 
improved sustainability of Tajikistan’s road network through increased 
financing  of  road  maintenance,  procurement  of  road  maintenance 
equipment, installation of vehicle weighing systems, and implementation 
of  pilot  cases  of  tendering  road  maintenance;  (iii)  strengthened 
institutional capacity of the Ministry of Transport (MOT); (iv) improved 
governance  in  MOT  through  the  strengthening  of  its  accounting 
department; and (v) improved road safety through the strengthening of 
the Transport Safety and Security Unit. 
   
Rationale  The road sections to be rehabilitated under the Project are bottlenecks 
to regional trade due to their poor condition. In particular, these road 
sections obstruct trade between much of Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and 
adjacent countries to the south, and the Kyrgyz Republic, the Xinjiang 
Uygur Autonomous Region of the PRC, and neighboring countries to 
the north. By improving key sections of the road from Dushanbe to the 
Tajik-Kyrgyz border, the Project will substantially reduce this obstruction 
to trade, and facilitate regional trade and cooperation. 
 
The project road provides the only substantial link between the Rasht 
Valley and Dushanbe. Before independence, the immediate project area 
in  the  Rasht  Valley  produced  large  quantities  of  fruit,  which  were 
marketed throughout the former Soviet Union. However, fruit production 
in the project area has declined substantially since independence. Many 
inhabitants  of  the  project  area  live  in  rural  areas  where  poverty 
incidence is particularly severe. The improvement of the Dushanbe–

Kyrgyz border road and selected rural roads will improve access to 
Dushanbe and other cities in the region, which have higher prices for 
agricultural products and more job opportunities than in the immediate 
project area. The Project will lead to reduced transport costs, most of 
which will be passed on to transport users. 
 
The Project includes a $500,000 ADF-IX grant-financed component on 
HIV/AIDS and migration, to be carried out by the Ministry of Health’s 
National  HIV/AIDS  Center.  The  ADF  grant-financed  component  will 
develop  an  integrated,  community-based  and  gender-responsive 
approach  to  the  prevention  of  HIV/AIDS  and  sexually-transmitted 
infections (STI). Subcomponents include (i) capacity development for 
local government agencies and NGOs, including training to implement 
the  Government’s  policies,  strategies,  and  regulations  in  HIV/STI 
prevention,  anti-trafficking,  and  regulation  of  migration;  (ii)  behavior 
change and communication for local communities and high-risk groups 
to reduce risks along the road corridor and establish an environment 
conducive  to  maintaining  safe  behavior  among  seasonal  migrants, 
women,  intravenous  drug  users,  sex  workers,  and  transport  and 
construction operators; and (iii) clinical support, through the provision of 
HIV testing kits and STI treatment packages to health clinics, to help 
them  meet  the  incremental  needs  of  mobile  populations  and  local 
communities. 
   
Impact and  The project impact will be increased trade in the region and increased 
Outcome  economic growth in the immediate project area. The project outcome 
will be improved and sustainable regional and national road networks. 
The  broader  region  served  by  the  road  network  being  rehabilitated 
under the Project stretches from Kazakhstan to Afghanistan, with links 
to  the  Russian  Federation  in  the  north,  the  PRC  to  the  east,  and 
Pakistan and Iran to the south. The immediate project area in the Rasht 
Valley northeast of Dushanbe was the scene of heavy fighting during 
the civil conflict in the 1990s.

regional trade. Improvement of the road will facilitate transport of fruit

lead to increased agricultural production. The economic internal rate of 
return for the Project is 15.4%, and the net present value is $9.8 million. 
Tajikistan is estimated to receive 76% of the Project’s net benefits; the

unskilled labor. 
   
Risks and  The Project has been designed to reduce potential risks, which include 
Assumptions  delays in implementation due to inadequate implementation capacity of 
the executing agency, failure to provide counterpart financing in a timely 
manner,  the  traffic  forecast  not  being  realized,  inadequate  road 
maintenance,  and  lack  of  security  in  the  project  area.  The  Project 
includes a number of measures to mitigate the risk of implementation 
delays. The existing PIU will implement the Project, and additional staff 
will  be  hired  to  assist  in  implementation.  Advance  action  has  been 
approved. The PIU is familiar with ADB procedures and will be able to 
make full use of the advance action provisions. The Government has 
assured  the  project  processing  missions  that  it  can  provide  the 
necessary funds for all ongoing ADB road rehabilitation projects in a 
timely manner. In addition, ADB is monitoring the Public Investment

disbursements to exceed agreed limits.  
 
There is some risk that the traffic forecast will not materialize, especially 
the generated traffic arising from increased international trade. There is 
also a risk that the project roads will not be properly maintained and 
thus the full benefits of the Project will not be realized. The Government 
is  aware  of  the  importance  of  road  maintenance,  particularly  in  the 
project area, which is mountainous and prone to landslides and rock 
falls.  The  project  design  includes  elements  to  address  the  risks  of 
inadequate financing and implementation of road maintenance for the 
project  roads.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  the  loan  assurances 
requiring the allocation of specific levels of financing for maintaining the 
project  roads,  in  addition  to  the  assurances  on  financing  for  road 
maintenance nationwide. The Project also includes procurement of road 
maintenance equipment, which will be used solely on the project roads. 
The immediate project area is in an area that was placed under a United 
Nations security restriction following the civil war. However, the security 
status was upgraded in late 2002 and again in September 2005 and is 
expected to remain in the upgraded condition.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz 
Border Road Rehabilitation Project (Phase II). 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
2.  The road sections to be improved under the Project form an integral part of a regional 
road network in Central Asia that directly links Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Uzbekistan. More broadly, this network is 
part of a larger network providing links to the ocean ports of Pakistan and Iran to the south, and 
to the Russian Federation to the north. The feasibility study for the Project was prepared 
through  an  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical  assistance  (TA).1  The  design  and 
monitoring framework for the proposed Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  Under the former Soviet Union (FSU), the regional road network existed only as part of 
an internal network, with no links to Afghanistan or the PRC. Following the breakup of the Soviet 
Union, the condition of the national roads comprising the network deteriorated substantially 
because of the decrease in financing for road maintenance in most countries (arising from 
budget constraints) and civil conflict in Tajikistan and Afghanistan. However, the situation has 
been improving over the last several years because financing for maintenance has generally 
been increasing and the civil conflicts have ended. Much of the regional road network is being 
rehabilitated by ADB and other international and bilateral agencies, with many of the projects 
already completed. The ADB-financed first phase of the rehabilitation of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz 
border  road  is  being  implemented.2  Among  the  recently  approved  projects  to  improve  the 
network are (i) the ADB-financed project to rehabilitate part of the road from Osh to the border 
with the PRC3 and (ii) the project financed by the Government of the United States to construct 
a  bridge  over  the  Pyandzh  River.  The  river  forms  the  border  between  Afghanistan  and 
Tajikistan, and is only passable by ferry and only during certain months. Additional projects to 
improve remaining sections of the network are planned. ADB’s regional program for Central 
Asia includes a loan to rehabilitate the remaining section of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz border road 
in Tajikistan (standby for 2007). The Islamic Development Bank and bilateral agencies are in 
talks with the governments of Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic to improve other network 
sections. However, the road link from Nurobod in Tajikistan to Sary Tash in the Kyrgyz Republic 
(on the road from Osh to the PRC–Kyrgyz Republic border) has not been rehabilitated. The 
sections of this road in Tajikistan, in particular, constitute a bottleneck to regional trade because 
of their poor condition. By removing this obstruction to trade, the Project will help realize the full 
benefits of the completed, ongoing, and planned projects for the network.

4.  The road subsector is the most important component of transport in Tajikistan. The 
combined length of the road network is about 26,000 kilometers (km), consisting of 4,800 km of 
national roads and 21,200 km of local roads. The Ministry of Transport (MOT) has jurisdiction 
over 13,800 km, including all national roads and 42% of the local roads (9,000 km). The 
remaining 12,300 km of local roads not under MOT are mostly rural and farm roads. The major 
part of the network was constructed before 1970. Inadequate maintenance, and damage from 
civil conflict and natural disasters have left it in a state of severe deterioration. Of the national 
roads, 28% are asphalt, 46% are other pavement, 18% are gravel, and 8% are earth. More than 
70% of the roads are considered to be in poor or very poor condition. The scope of the network 
is considered adequate to accommodate existing traffic levels and support economic growth 
and sustainable development in the medium term as the network was constructed during the 
Soviet era, when transport demand was much higher. Since independence, the road transport 
fleet  has  been  increasingly  privatized  and  private  automobile  ownership  has  significantly 
increased. A road subsector analysis and the Transport Sector Policy Reform Plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Obstacles to Development 
 
5.  Regional Cooperation. Increasing trade is key to accelerating economic growth and 
reducing poverty in Central Asia, particularly in Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic, with their 
small populations and limited natural resources (except for hydropower). Even in the Central 
Asian republics (CARs) with more natural resources—such as Kazakhstan and the Xinjiang 
Uygur  Autonomous  Region  of  the  PRC  (Xinjiang)—the  contribution  of  trade  to  increased 
economic  growth  is  constrained  by  their  landlocked  status  and  distances  to  ocean  ports. 
Improvement of the regional road network is therefore essential to increase economic growth. 
Three core problems constrain the development of regional road transport in the CARs: (i) lack 
of  a  unified  regulatory  framework  that  encourages  competition,  (ii)  delays  and  excessive 
charges at borders, and (iii) physical deterioration of the network.4 ADB is involved in solving all 
these problems. Development of a unified regulatory framework is one of the issues being dealt 
with as part of the Transport Sector Coordinating Committee’s work under the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) program. Regional cooperation in improving customs 
processing is being promoted under regional projects such as the ADB-financed Regional 
Customs Modernization and Infrastructure Development Project.5 The deterioration of the road 
network  is  being  addressed  through  a  two-pronged  approach.  First,  ADB  is  continuing  its 
assistance program to improve roads comprising part of the regional network. Second, the 
implementation  of  these  projects  includes  policy  dialogue  to  increase  financing  for  road 
maintenance and to carry out institutional reforms to improve the efficiency of the maintenance 
system. The Project will continue to improve the road network through both of these avenues. 
 
6.  The road sections to be rehabilitated under the Project form a bottleneck that obstructs 
trade between much of Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and adjacent countries to the south; and Osh in 
the Kyrgyz Republic (a traditional crossroads for trade), Xinjiang (with its population of 19 million 
and  dynamic  economy),  and  neighboring  countries  to  the  north.  The  significance  of  this 
bottleneck is evident in the PRC’s share of total trade of countries in the region. Kazakhstan and

substantial benefits for the region. In addition to the direct benefits from increased trade, the 
Project will improve efficiency in the region’s economies. The reduced transport costs and 
removal of the bottleneck to regional trade will result in increased demand for exports and 
imports,  thus  increasing  the  profitability  of  export-oriented  industries  and  decreasing  the 
profitability of import-substituting industries. Economic resources will therefore shift from the 
import-substituting industries to export-oriented industries, and increase economic efficiency. 
This shift will also lead to increased employment, since export industries include agriculture and 
light industry such as textiles. In the medium-term, this shift of resources to sectors in which 
countries have comparative advantages will increase total output and living standards through 
more efficient resource allocation and increased productivity.6 Because some of these benefits 
arise from economic adjustments occurring over the medium-term and data are insufficient, the 
economic analysis follows a conservative approach limited to direct benefits accruing primarily 
to Tajikistan, the PRC, the Kyrgyz Republic, and Afghanistan (para. 54). 
 
8.  Economic  Growth  and  Poverty  Reduction.  Tajikistan  has  significantly  reduced 
poverty in recent years. Strong economic growth, policy reforms, and a favorable economic 
environment led to sustained poverty reduction from 82% in 1999 to 64% in 2003. However, 
poverty is still highest among the CARs, with a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of 
$310 in 2004.7 Although poverty in the project area has also been reduced, it is still higher than 
for the country. Poverty incidence in the project area is estimated at 68%—significantly lower 
than the 91% estimated for the project area for phase I, which is adjacent to the project area for 
phase II. Poverty in the project area was reduced primarily because of increased remittances 
from residents working in the Russian Federation, rather than because of increased agricultural 
production, the primary source of livelihood. Before independence, the project area in the Rasht 
Valley had large orchards and was a large producer of fruit that was marketed throughout the 
FSU. Fruit production in the project area has declined substantially since independence, and is 
estimated at only 50% of production capacity. The decline is due to (i) destruction from the civil 
conflict, (ii) disappearance of previous markets, (iii) the absence of an effective marketing 
system to replace what was used in the FSU, and (iv) the deterioration in road conditions, which 
resulted in high costs for transport and damage to produce. Fruit production requires a relatively 
long-term investment, as orchards are generally not substantially productive until 7–8 years 
after planting. Rehabilitation of the project road is a prerequisite for investment in orchards and 
for economic growth in the project area.

1.  Road Subsector Sustainability 
 
21.  Road Maintenance Financing. Increasing the financing of road maintenance is key to 
improving the sustainability of the road subsector. Both ongoing road subsector projects include

increase allocations for maintenance, and to ensure that maintenance has high priority among 
total  sector  expenditures.  First,  the  covenants  require  annual  real  increases  in  budget 
allocations  for  road  maintenance  and  rehabilitation.  Second,  the  covenants  require  that 
allocations for road maintenance and rehabilitation comprise specified percentages of total road 
subsector expenditures. Allocations for road maintenance and rehabilitation are required to be 
increased by 15% per year during 2005–2007 and to comprise at least 80% of total road 
subsector  spending,  excluding  the  construction  of  the  Anzob  Tunnel  on  the  Dushanbe–

22.  The Government has exceeded the targets for annual increases in financing for road 
maintenance  and  rehabilitation.  Approved  budget  allocations  for  road  maintenance  and 
rehabilitation increased substantially in 2004 and 2005. The allocation for 2005 is 57% higher 
than in 2004. Compliance with the covenant requiring that road maintenance and rehabilitation 
comprise at least 80% of total road subsector spending has been more challenging, although 
performance is improving. The proportion was 59% in 2004 for actual expenditures, and has 
improved to 79% for 2005. The covenant excludes from the proportion expenditures for the 
construction of the Anzob Tunnel. If expenditures for the construction of avalanche galleries on 
the approaches leading up to the tunnel are excluded, the proportions for 2004 and 2005 
increase to 76% and 86% respectively, bringing the Government into compliance for 2005.

maintenance. It will ensure that actual expenditures for maintenance (including emergency

C.  Asian Development Fund IX Grant Component on HIV/AIDS and Migration

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
50.  Traffic forecasts by vehicle type were prepared for the project road sections for 2006–
2029 (Appendix 9). The forecasts are based on expected growth in GDP, income elasticities of 
demand, and analysis of regional trade patterns. Total traffic is forecast to grow at annual rates 
of  11.5–15.8%  during  2006–2015  (the  years  during  and  immediately  following  project 
implementation), except for the border section, which has higher growth. The high growth rates 
during these years are due in large part to the high growth of international traffic and completion 
of the Project and the preceding first phase. Total traffic is forecast to grow at annual rates of 
about 6.0% during 2016–2029. Average annual growth rates for normal and domestic generated 
traffic are estimated at 6.9–7.2% during 2006–2010, 6.0–6.5% during 2011–2015, and 5.9–
6.2% from 2016 onwards. Domestic generated traffic arises from increased passenger traffic 
and transport of produce to Dushanbe. The improved road condition lowers vehicle operating 
costs (VOCs) and generates demand through lower fares. It causes less damage to fruit during 
shipment, thereby increasing the demand for production and transport from the project area to 
Dushanbe.   
 
51.  International generated traffic is forecast based on an analysis of trade patterns in the 
region and potential trade from improved access to ports in Pakistan. Three pairs of trading 
partners were examined: Tajikistan-the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan-the PRC, and the PRC-
Afghanistan. Improvement of the regional road network, where project road sections constitute a 
major bottleneck, will provide a much more direct and efficient transport route for trade among 
these country pairs. The PRC’s share of Tajikistan’s total trade is estimated to increase from 
1.9% now to 20.0% by 2014, still lower than the PRC’s 23.0% share of the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
trade. Similarly, the PRC’s share of Afghanistan’s total trade is estimated to increase from 
0.04% now to 10.00% by 2014. International generated traffic is forecast to increase by 43.1% 
during 2011–2015, and by 5.9% from 2016 onwards. The high growth rate during 2011–2015 
will be due to the increase in PRC’s share of total trade for Tajikistan and Afghanistan, which 
will reach levels similar to those of other countries in the region. Normal traffic is expected to 
account for 46–52% of total traffic on the project road in 2029, except for the border section, 
where it comprises only 6%. Domestic generated traffic resulting from lower transport costs 
arising  from  the  Project  accounts  for  2%  or  less  on  the  four  road  sections.  International 
generated traffic comprises 34%–53% of total traffic in 2029, except for the border section, 
where it comprises 94%. 
 
B.  Economic Benefits 
 
52.  The economic analysis was carried out for the Project by comparing the with- and 
without-project scenarios (Appendix 10). In the without-project scenario, the road is assumed to 
receive only minimal maintenance and will continue to deteriorate. The with-project scenario

18 
includes routine and periodic maintenance according to international standards. The PPTA 
considered various mutually exclusive project alternatives, and the proposed Project is based 
on the most cost-effective and least-cost option. 
 
53.  Project  economic  costs  include  the  resource  costs  of  road  improvement  and 
maintenance (including rural roads), equipment, and consulting services. The primary economic 
benefits for the Project are VOC savings for normal traffic, domestic and international generated 
traffic,  and  benefits  arising  from  improvement  of  the  rural  roads.  Economic  benefits  were 
calculated using the same methodology used for costs. VOC savings will accrue primarily from 
improvements in the road surface, horizontal and vertical alignment, and increased average 
speed on some sections. VOC savings for normal traffic account for about 58% of total benefits, 
and benefits from international generated traffic account for about 37%. Benefits for generated 
traffic are estimated at half the value of VOC savings for normal traffic. Domestic generated 
traffic is defined as new traffic resulting from reduced transport costs arising from the Project. 
International generated traffic comprises new international traffic arising from increased trade 
among  Tajikistan,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  the  PRC  and  from  improved  access  to  ports 
resulting from improvement of the project road. The Project will have other benefits, such as 
improved access to social services and improved road safety. However, these have not been 
quantified because data is insufficient. 
 
54.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated for the Project, including the 
rural roads and all other components. The EIRR for the overall Project is 15.4%, and the net 
present value is $9.8 million, using a 12% discount rate. The EIRR including only benefits 
accruing to Tajikistan is 11.9%. In addition to the direct benefits that have been quantified in the 
economic analysis, the Project will yield substantial other benefits for Tajikistan. The immediate 
project area was the scene of heavy fighting during the civil conflict in the 1990s, and the 
Government places a high priority on integrating this region—economically and politically—with 
the  rest  of  the  country,  which  requires  improvement  of  the  project  road.  The  substantial 
economic benefits arising from increased trade (para. 7) will have a major impact on Tajikistan. 
The improved road will lead to decreased prices for imported consumer goods, as goods from 
the region replace those currently imported from the Russian Federation, which will result in 
substantial consumer surplus benefits for the population. Likewise, reduced prices for imported 
inputs will make exports such as agricultural and light industrial products more competitive and 
lead to increased production. These products require labor-intensive production and will lead to 
increased  employment.  Sensitivity  analysis  was  carried  out  to  test  the  effects  of  negative 
changes in the key parameters that determine the project benefits and costs. The sensitivity 
analysis indicates that either capital costs would have to increase by 44%, or total benefits 
decrease by 29% for the EIRR to decrease to 12%. International generated traffic would have to 
decrease by 80% for the EIRR to drop to 12%. Given ADB’s experience with similar projects in 
Tajikistan and other CARs, such changes are not expected. 
 
55.  A distribution analysis found that Tajikistan would receive 76% of net benefits: the PRC, 
12%; the Kyrgyz Republic, 6%; Afghanistan, 5%; and other countries, 1%. Tajikistan’s share of 
total net benefits attributable to regional benefits would be 6%. Tajikistan would receive regional 
benefits from lower prices for imports, sourced from the PRC via the project road, and from 
increased exports to the PRC and other countries to the north. The PRC would receive regional 
benefits largely from increased exports to Tajikistan and Afghanistan. The Kyrgyz Republic 
would receive regional benefits from increased trade with Tajikistan and to a lesser extent 
Afghanistan, as well as from increased trade arising from improved access to ports in Pakistan. 
The Kyrgyz Republic would also benefit from border-crossing fees for international traffic at the 
PRC–Kyrgyz Republic border at Irkeshtam and from small-scale businesses providing services,

19
e.g., food and vehicle repair, for transit traffic. Afghanistan’s share of regional benefits would 
arise primarily from lower prices for imports from the PRC and from increased exports to 
countries  to  the  north.  Kazakhstan  and  other  countries  in  the  region  would  benefit  from 
improved access to ports in Pakistan; the reduced transport costs of reaching these ocean ports 
would facilitate increased trade. In the longer term, the Project would likely facilitate the Kyrgyz 
Republic’s and Tajikistan’s trade with India. A conservative approach was used in the estimates 
of the regional benefits, which are based on estimates of increased trade of three pairs of 
regional trading partners and on the increased trade arising from improved access to ports in 
Pakistan provided by the project road. The project benefits accruing to Tajikistan are distributed 
among five national groups: (i) users of freight transport, (ii) users of passenger transport, (iii) 
vehicle owners, (iv) labor, and (v) the Government and/or economy of Tajikistan. Users of 
passenger and freight transport, and the Government and/or economy each receive about 22–
23% of total benefits. Because the market for transport services in the project area is highly 
competitive, vehicle owners only retain about 5% of net benefits.  
 
56.  A financial analysis examined the project impact on the financial status of MOT and the 
Government, particularly the financial impact of the maintenance and operational costs that will 
arise from the Project. The additional real maintenance costs of $90,000 per year represent less 
than 2.0% of MOT’s budget for road rehabilitation and maintenance. Based on the analysis

D.  Poverty Reduction Impact 
 
58.  As a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union and the civil war that followed, poverty 
levels  in  Tajikistan  became  very  high.  Although  the  country  is  now  recovering,  the 
socioeconomic  survey  undertaken  for  the  Project  revealed  that  an  estimated  68%  of  the 
population and 62% of the households in the affected area have an income per head of less 
than TJS600 per year, which has been identified as a suitable poverty benchmark. Even people 
with regular employment and who travel regularly are living in poverty because of low wages 
and large households. As a result, the poor are well represented among road users and are 
potential beneficiaries. Unlike in many other countries, a high proportion of the poor own motor 
vehicles—albeit  old  ones  in  use  since  the  FSU.  There  are  no  large  commercial  transport 
operators, but there is a highly competitive market of owner-drivers, as the supply of commercial 
transport services exceeds demand. VOC savings are therefore likely to be passed on as 
reduced costs, fares, and charges. The impact on fares will be tracked as part of the monitoring 
and evaluation procedures agreed on for the Project. 
 
59.  The project area’s population consists largely of rural people, most of whom are farmers. 
The Project will reduce poverty by lowering the transport costs for farm produce and for people 
traveling to agricultural and labor markets, health and education centers, and other social and 
public services. The poverty assessment shows that the Project will significantly reduce poverty. 
It will directly benefit about 180,000 people in the 26 districts adjacent to the project road; and

20 
road  users  from  outside  the  immediate  project  area,  who  use  the  project  road  to  access 
Dushanbe. Of the domestic beneficiaries, an estimated 120,000 poor people will be direct 
beneficiaries. Others will benefit from lower transport costs leading to reduced consumer prices 
and generated economic and social development. The Project will generate many skilled and 
unskilled  jobs  during  implementation.  Unskilled  labor  will  be  employed  directly  in  road 
construction, and indirectly in provision of materials and support services. The Project will create 
about 45,000 person-months of unskilled labor for the rehabilitation of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz 
border road and 5,000 person-months for the rural roads. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 12. 
 
E.  Social and Gender Impact 
 
60.  Men and women achieved considerable social and economic gains under the FSU, but 
gender  equality  has  been  undermined  since  independence.  Social  relations  have  been 
disrupted by changes such as the privatization of economic assets, giving rise to new economic 
relations among families, communities, and the Government. Access to resources required for 
survival was further limited during the civil war, with corresponding influence on social and 
gender relations. The conflicts between traditional values and current economic needs are 
mediated within families, but the conflicts between traditional values and gender roles are more 
difficult to mediate. Women are expected to uphold traditional values while contributing to their 
families’ livelihoods. Traditional gender roles and expectations of girls and women limit their 
access to education, skills, resources such as land and, frequently to knowledge of the outside 
world. Pressure on men to meet all their families’ needs is also strong, and this stress is 
sometimes expressed as domestic violence or psychological harassment. In the immediate 
project area, many more men than women access postsecondary education. Out of the 210 
surveyed households, only 2% of the women had attended vocational schools and/or colleges 
compared with 17% of men. Females reported lower literacy. While men have a wide range of 
job opportunities, women are predominantly engaged in cropping (78%) and tending livestock 
(13%). The average income of women was only 60% that of men. Many men migrate to the 
Russian Federation for seasonal employment and repatriate income. These remittances are the 
largest source of household income in the project area. 
 
61.  The Project will have indirect and direct benefits for women. Indirect benefits are mostly 
related to enhanced connectivity and include increased access to education and health facilities; 
increased travel to towns; increased marketability of women’s products (fruits and vegetables); 
increased access to jobs (in local markets); and increased access to information. Women will 
benefit from outside ideas as access to the rest of the country improves. A direct benefit is the 
adoption of an integrated and community-based approach to HIV/AIDS and migration (paras. 
32–33), targeting local communities and high-risk groups.  
 
F.  Resettlement Effects 
 
62.  All the civil works activities will take place either within the existing right-of-way or on 
unused  state-owned  land.  No  relocation  of  households  or  acquisition  of  productive  land  is 
expected. If the Project needs new borrow pits or quarries, they are expected to be located on 
unused state-owned land. The Project will directly affect 10 households at most in Garm and 
Yangolik village. Of the 10 households, 2 are headed by females. The income per capita per year 
of the 10 households is less than TJS500, with 80% of their income coming from agriculture. One 
small shop partly located on the right-of-way will be affected, with its entrance moved by 2 meters 
from the right-of-way. An SRP was formulated in accordance with the laws and regulations of 
Tajikistan,  and  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995).  The  resettlement  strategy,

compensation standards, entitlements, and rehabilitation plans were based on impact surveys and 
consultations with local officials and affected households. Considering that the impact on towns 
and villages will be minimal and most of the affected persons have larger incomes than average, 
the  SRP will be implemented smoothly.  Demolition of structures on  the  right-of-way  will be 
completed  within  2006,  and  compensation  will  be  paid  before  the  civil  works  start.  Special 
attention will be paid to the two female-headed households and the small-shop owner to prevent 
their marginalization or impoverishment. A summary of the SRP is in Appendix 13. 
 
G.  Risks 
 
63.  The  Project  has  been  designed  to  reduce  potential  risks,  which  include  delays  in 
implementation  because  of  inadequate  implementation  capacity  of  MOT,  failure  to  provide 
counterpart  financing  on  time,  the  traffic  forecast  not  being  realized,  inadequate  road 
maintenance,  and  lack  of  security  in  the  project  area.  The  Project  includes  a  number  of 
measures to mitigate the risk of delays. The existing PIU will implement the Project and has 
identified the number and type of additional staff members needed. Advance action has been 
approved, and the PIU is now familiar with ADB procedures and will be able to make full use of 
the advance action provisions. The Government has been made aware of ADB’s emphasis on 
the timely provision of counterpart funds, and has assured the project processing missions that 
it can provide the necessary funds for all ongoing ADB-financed road projects on time. Project 
disbursements  will  be  within  the  Public  Investment  Program  restrictions  agreed  to  by  the 
Government and the International Monetary Fund.  
 
64.  There is some risk that the traffic forecast will not materialize, especially the generated 
traffic  arising  from  increased  international  trade.  This  risk  has  been  mitigated  by  using 
conservative assumptions to estimate benefits from international generated traffic, as only the 
benefits from increased trade of three pairs of regional trading partners and additional traffic 
arising from improved access to ports has been included. There is also a risk that the project 
roads will not be properly maintained and thus the full benefits of the Project will not be realized. 
The Government is aware of the importance of road maintenance, particularly in the project 
area, which is mountainous and prone to landslides and rock falls. The project design includes 
elements  to  address  the  risks  of  inadequate  financing  and  the  implementation  of  road 
maintenance for the project roads. The Government has agreed to loan assurances requiring 
the allocation of specific levels of financing for maintaining the project roads, in addition to the 
assurances  regarding  levels  of  financing  for  road  maintenance  nationwide.  The  additional 
maintenance costs amount to less than 2.0% of MOT’s budget for road maintenance and 
rehabilitation, and will be sustainable. The Project includes procurement of road maintenance 
equipment, which will be used solely on the project roads. A sensitivity analysis indicates that 
the Project remains economically feasible, with an EIRR of 13.2%, even with only 50.0% of the 
required maintenance provided. The project area is part of an area placed under a United 
Nations security restriction following the civil war. However, the security status was upgraded in 
late 2002, and again in September 2005. It is expected to remain in the upgraded condition.

ROAD SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Subsector Description  
 
1.  The road subsector is the most important component of domestic transport in Tajikistan. 
The road network is discussed in the main text. 
 
B.  Road Administration 
 
2.  Prior to the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) involvement with Tajikistan’s transport 
sector, the Transport Department under the Office of the President acted as the central point of 
coordination  for  the  transport  sector.  Development  planning  for  the  subsectors  was  the 
responsibility  of  separate  government  organizations.  The  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Roads 
served as the national agency for road infrastructure management. It managed road transport 
enterprises, allocated budgets, assigned work, and managed personnel. The Tajik Railway 
Company served as the agency for railways, while the Tajikistan State Air Company served as 
the agency for civil aviation and airports. Each organization was responsible for preparing 
development plans and investment programs for its own subsector. During the implementation 
of the development plans, the Office of the President provided coordination for review and 
revision  of  the  investment  programs  and  for  allocation  of  investment  funds  among  the 
subsectors.  
 
3.  As a result of policy dialogue with and technical assistance from ADB, the administration 
of the transport sector was reorganized and the Ministry of Transport (MOT) was created. MOT, 
which  now  regulates  Tajikistan  Railway  (Tajik  Rail)  and  Tajikistan  Airlines  (Tajik  Air),  is 
responsible  for  planning  and  coordinating  all  modes  of  transport  within  the  country.  The 
Government is committed to develop a transport sector that meets the needs of a market-based 
economy. The reorganized MOT reflects a policy of promoting competition, increasing the 
private sector's role, and enabling customers to make informed decisions. In the future, most 
state-owned enterprises will play a minor role and will be expected to operate as independent 
commercial enterprises.  
 
4.  Separate deputy ministers are responsible for rail transport and air transport. These are 
regulatory and oversight responsibilities only and the line functions remain with Tajik Rail and 
Tajik  Air.  MOT’s  Roads  Department  is  responsible  for  administration,  maintenance,  and 
construction of roads in Tajikistan, and has a number of associated entities. For example, 
Tajikgiprotransstroy (the Design Institute, a joint stock company) is responsible for surveys, 
testing of materials, design of maintenance, and new construction in the subsector. 
 
C.  Road Standards and Safety 
 
5.  Tajikistan’s road standards and specifications are based on those of the former Soviet 
Union (FSU). Several studies have indicated that the design standards of FSU state roads 
implemented in national roads in Tajikistan are sometimes higher than those of the United 
States or European countries. However, they do not always result in optimum road design. For 
lower-standard roads, FSU standards for design speed and cross sections are similar to those 
used in developing countries, but for higher-category roads, they are excessive. The quality of 
construction of Tajikistan’s roads is generally inadequate, mainly because of a lack of cost-
effective construction techniques and independent construction supervision. Road safety is 
discussed in the main text.

D.  Road Transport Industry 
 
6.  Major  changes  have  occurred  in  the  road  transport  industry  since  independence, 
especially in the commercialization, and in some cases privatization, of the industry. In 1998, 
the Government had jurisdiction over 81 road transport service enterprises. Most intercity bus 
and trucking operations are now organized as joint stock companies, with various shares of 
public and private ownership. For example, of the 52 medium and large transport organizations 
that were formerly part of MOT and designated by the Government for privatization, 73% are 
wholly owned by the Government, 6% are wholly privately owned, and 21% have mixed public-
private ownership. As of March 2002, 5,226 vehicles were operated by joint stock companies 
and other organizations within MOT. Of these, 3,627 vehicles or 69% were operated by four 
joint stock companies (Badakshonnakliyot, Khatlontrans, Khudjandnaklyot, and Kulyabtrans). 
The remaining vehicles were operated by other MOT departments, Tajik Air, and Tajik Rail. A 
significant portion of trucking and most long-distance bus services are operated by private 
companies.  Tariffs  for  road  freight  have  been  completely  deregulated;  road  haulage 
organizations enter into agreements with customers at negotiated rates. Tariffs for passenger 
transport  are  still  regulated.  MOT  and  the  Ministry  of  Economy  jointly  establish  tariffs  for 
passenger transport for buses, minibuses, and taxis for urban and long-distance services. While 
these official tariffs should be charged by all operators, many bus and minibus operators charge 
market fares, according to what they think people will pay, and do not follow the official tariff. 
 
E.  Road Subsector Revenue and Expenditure 
 
7.  The state budget allocation for road rehabilitation and maintenance varies from year to 
year  according  to  the  Government's  priorities  and  fiscal  constraints.  Prior  to  2000,  road 
subsector expenditures were financed from the Road Fund, the state budget, and development 
agencies. The Road Fund had four main sources: (i) road-user and other taxes, such as excise 
taxes on purchases of vehicles and parts, tires, fuel, and lubricants; and also including a 2.5% 
tax on transactions by all companies that is generally not considered a road-user tax; (ii) 
charges on international transit shipments; (iii) vehicle inspection fees and registration fees; and 
(iv) contributions from local governments. In practice, only half of the Road Fund collection was 
allocated  to  road  rehabilitation  and  maintenance;  the  other  half  was  used  to  fund  new 
construction.  As  a  result  of  general  fiscal  constraints  and  allocations  to  new  construction, 
expenditures on road maintenance and rehabilitation have been much lower than what was 
needed  to  maintain  the  road  network  at  an  acceptable  level.  In  2000,  the  Government 
terminated the Road Fund to meet the International Monetary Fund requirement to maintain one 
consolidated state budget.1 The taxes and receipts formerly contributing to the Road Fund are 
still  collected,  but  now  are  paid  directly  to  the  national  treasury.  Road  maintenance  and 
construction are now funded from the general state budget. The following amounts have been 
allocated  to  the  road  subsector  in  the  national  budget  for  2005:  TJS18.1  million  for 
maintenance, TJS18.7 million for new construction (of which TJS12.2 million is for the Anzob 
Tunnel),  and  TJS4.3  million  for  rehabilitation,  for  a  total  of  TJS41.1  million.  These  are 
approximately equivalent to the following amounts: $5.7 million for maintenance, $5.9 million for 
new construction, and $1.4 million for rehabilitation, for a total of $13.0 million. Details on the 
current status of road subsector financing are discussed in the main text.

F.  Road Maintenance 
 
8.  MOT is responsible for planning and coordinating the maintenance of Tajikistan's road 
network.  MOT  maintains  roads  and  bridges  through  five  regional  road  departments: 
Badakhshan, Dushanbe, Khatlon and Kulyab (combined in 2005), Khudjand, and Rasht. These 
road  maintenance  departments  are  responsible  for  approximately  13,800  km  of  road,  and 
employ 2,981 people. The departments are state entities attached to MOT and are composed of 
road maintenance units (RMUs). None of the departments or RMUs has been privatized. While 
it is the stated intention of MOT to eventually privatize them, no progress has been made to 
date. The road maintenance departments prepare annual plans and budgets based on systems 
established during the Soviet era. This information is then presented to MOT, which in turn 
allocates funding to the various departments. The RMUs are responsible for the part of the road 
network within their jurisdiction, with the actual maintenance being carried out by staff who are 
responsible for specific sections of the road. However, the plant, equipment, and materials 
available to the workforce are generally not sufficient for carrying out effective maintenance 
activities. The Rasht Road Department and the Dushanbe Road Department are responsible for 
maintenance of roads in the Regions of Republican Subordination. The Rasht Road Department 
is responsible for maintenance of the road to be improved under the Project. The Rasht Road 
Department is responsible for maintaining 885 km of roads, is composed of 9 RMUs, and 
employs 237 people. The Dushanbe Road Department is responsible for maintenance of the 
road sections being rehabilitated under the first phase.

HIV/AIDS AND MIGRATION COMPONENT 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Tajikistan  is  at  an  early  stage  of  an  HIV/AIDS1  epidemic.  The  number  of  officially 
registered HIV cases remains low, with 385 cases (321 males, 64 females), mostly under 30 
(127 males, 38 females) and under 40 years of age (140 males, 17 females) as of May 2005.2 
The methods of HIV transmission among registered cases include injected drug use (59.7%), 
sexual transmission (8%), and unknown (30.9%). However, these data may not accurately 
reflect the real situation. Diagnostic capacity is low and the social stigma and discrimination 
associated with infection mean few of those who are most at risk are tested. The real number of 
HIV infections may be 10–20 times higher. 
 
2.  Economic stagnation and lack of employment opportunities during and after Tajikistan’s 
civil war in the 1990s have resulted in a rapid rise in cross-border seasonal migration. About 
600,000 people (or 10% of the population) leave each year, mostly to the Russian Federation, in 
search  of  informal  income  opportunities.  According  to  the  International  Organization  for 
Migration (IOM), initial migration patterns involved mostly unskilled young males (ages 20–29), 
though most recent trends suggest increasing migration of older males (ages 40–49). The 
project area in the Rasht Valley is known as a traditional source of migrants. Migrant workers 
are a high risk category for contracting HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs), 
having typically two to three sexual partners over the course of an 8- or 9-month work season 
abroad.3 Younger male migrants use commercial sex workers more frequently than older men 
and, considering the high prevalence of HIV infections in the Russian Federation, a majority of 
these migrants are at very high risk of passing STIs to their sexual partners at home. 
 
3.  Limited understanding of contraception and strong feelings against the use of condoms 
among men are reflected in the poor understanding of sexual behavior, or the unwillingness to 
change it. In 2003, only 2% of women between ages 15 and 49 reported using condoms,4 which 
are associated with sex workers and sex outside marriage. These issues are rarely discussed in 
public, and there is widespread belief that HIV and other STIs are diseases that only prostitutes 
and the dissolute can contract. These attitudes make it difficult for wives to raise the subject of 
the need for protection against STIs with their returning husbands, especially in more traditional 
communities. There is also a profound stigma against those who are infected, discouraging 
testing and open discussion of HIV and other STIs. Most Tajik labor migrants have irregular 
status in their countries of destination. The health of migrants in an irregular situation can be at 
risk due to poverty, discrimination, vulnerability to labor exploitation, separation from families 
and  partners,  separation  from  the  sociocultural  norms  that  guide  behavior  in  stable 
communities, and, often, lack of access to health care and social services. 
 
4.  Tajikistan is also a country of origin for trafficked persons, mostly women. Two types of 
trafficking prevail, both of which are increasing rapidly: labor exploitation, e.g., sweatshops in 
the  Russian  Federation,  and  trafficking  in  women  and  children  for sexual  exploitation  and 
domestic servitude, mostly to the Middle East. According to data received from the Ministry of 
Interior (2005) more than 58 trafficking cases were registered between January 2004 and March 
2005. Many Tajik women transit through Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, and the Kyrgyz Republic to 
travel to the Middle East or the Russian Federation. Recent evidence from IOM’s work with

B.  Objective and Scope 
 
5.  The HIV/AIDS and migration component is designed to mitigate the risks of HIV and 
STIs—in a context characterized by cross-border seasonal migration and human trafficking—
during and after the implementation of the proposed Project. This will be done by supporting 
local governments, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and communities to develop and 
implement an integrated and gender-responsive approach to HIV/AIDS and STI prevention in 
the construction campsites and corridor of influence. The project area covers three districts in 
the Regions of Republican Subordination (Nurobod, Rasht, and Tajikabad) with 26 jamoats (or 
villages) and a population of about 180,000. It includes Karamik, the 12-km section at the Tajik–
Kyrgyz border. The project area in the Rasht Valley is characterized by a combination of 
gender-relevant  factors,  which  have  to  be  considered in  the  design  of  HIV/STI  prevention 
programs.  These  include  traditional  rural  societies,  seasonal  male  labor  migration  to  the 
Russian Federation, conservative religious beliefs and associated gender-based practices, a 
high  percentage  of  female-headed  households  (including  war  widows),  women’s  lack  of 
employable skills, increasing drug trafficking and consumption patterns, and HIV/AIDS and STI 
stigmas and discrimination. 
 
C.  Project Subcomponents 
 
6.  Baseline information data on HIV/AIDS, migration, and human trafficking patterns in the 
project area, including a list of local government and NGO stakeholders, will be gathered based 
on existing quantitative and qualitative data.5 
 
7.  Subcomponent  1:  Capacity  Development  for  Local  Government  Agencies  and 
NGOs. This subcomponent will consist of training local government authorities (Departments of 
Health,  Education,  Labor  and  Social  Protection,  Statistics  Committees,  and  Women’s 
Committees)  and  enforcement  agencies  (police  and  border  guards)  in  the  project  area  in 
effectively implementing the Government’s policies, strategies, and regulations in the prevention 
of HIV/AIDS and other STIs, anti-trafficking, and the regulation of migration in the project area. 
The training module will be developed by an international organization and will build upon the 
demonstrated success of approaches in the project area. Training of selected local NGOs will 
be based on their involvement in and/or potential to increase the outreach and impact of 
HIV/AIDS prevention, anti-trafficking, and regulation of migration in the project area. The training 
module will be developed by the international organization and relevant government agencies. It 
will provide (i) technical skills (social, gender, and medical and psychological expertise related 
to HIV/AIDS, human trafficking, and migration); (ii) administrative, financial, and management 
skills; (iii) proposal writing skills, to ensure quality proposals and sustainable access to donor 
funding; and (iv) development of behavior change communication (BCC) strategy and materials 
for local communities. Upon successful completion of the training, local NGOs will be involved in 
the implementation of the BCC initiatives. 
 
8.  Subcomponent 2: Behavior Change and Communication for Local Communities 
and High-risk Groups. In the context of an AIDS epidemic, BCC is an essential part of a 
comprehensive program that includes services (medical, social, psychological, and spiritual) 
and commodities (e.g., condoms, needles, and syringes). This subcomponent aims to reduce

9.  Subcomponent 3: Clinical Support. HIV testing kits and STI treatment packages will 
be provided to health clinics to help meet the incremental needs of mobile populations and local 
communities.  These  will  also  complement  existing  programs  supported  by  the  National 
HIV/AIDS Center, United Nations agencies, and other donors. Condoms will be made available 
free of charge to construction workers, local communities, and target and high-risk groups for 
about 2.5 years. A limited number of condoms will be distributed during the first year of road 
rehabilitation as part of marketing efforts. The component will closely consult with the National 
HIV/AIDS Center and the Global Fund to fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria (Global Fund) on 
sustainable  condom  distribution  during  road  rehabilitation.  Training  to  health  workers  and 
laboratory technicians will be provided under the aegis of the National HIV/AIDS Center and 
involve  (i)  training,  consultation,  and  operational  support  to  health  workers  for  clinical

technicians on epidemiological surveillance and laboratory diagnosis. Training activities will be 
further defined by the National HIV/AIDS Center based on the specific needs and constraints 
faced by health workers and laboratory technicians at the rapid testing centers in Rogun and 
Garm, and at the Trust Center for Migrants in Garm. Clinical support activities will complement 
the Global Fund's efforts to strengthen HIV/AIDS diagnostic infrastructure. 
 
10.  The HIV/AIDS and migration component has been designed in consultation with the 
Ministry of Health’s National HIV/AIDS Center to ensure consistency with the priority directions 
on HIV/AIDS prevention set forth by the National Coordination Committee (2000). These priority 
directions  were  further  defined  in  the  National  Strategic  Plan  to  respond  to  the  HIV/AIDS 
epidemic  (2002).  Discussions  with  UNAIDS6  and  the  Global  Fund  confirmed  the  lack  of 
significant  community-based  HIV/AIDS  and  STI  preventive  activities  in  the  project  area. 
Consultations  with  UNDP,  UNIFEM,  IOM,  the  Open  Society  Institute,  the  Aga  Khan 
Development Network, and CARE provided valuable insights into lessons learned in the design 
and implementation of the HIV/AIDS and STI prevention program in Tajikistan. These lessons 
were incorporated in the design of the component.

E.  Implementation Arrangement 
 
12.  The Ministry of Health, through its National HIV/AIDS Center, will be the Executing 
Agency  for  the  component.  The  Ministry  of  Health  will  engage  a  qualified  international 
organization (which could be an international NGO, consulting firm, or other entity) to manage 
and coordinate the implementation of the component. The international organization, which may 
associate with local consultants or NGOs, will be recruited by quality- and cost-based selection 
using  simplified  technical  proposals,  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory for the engagement of domestic consultants. 
The international organization will consult with the National HIV/AIDS Center on the design of 
the capacity development activities for local government agencies and NGOs (subcomponent 
1), and involve local government agencies and NGOs in the implementation of BCC initiatives 
(subcomponent 2). It will work with the National HIV/AIDS Center in the identification of training 
needs, selection of consultants, preparation of training materials, and procurement of equipment 
and supplies for STI treatment and voluntary counseling and testing (subcomponent 3). The 
terms of reference for the international organization is in (supplementary Appendix D). 
 
13.  At the central level, the international organization will be responsible for organizing 
quarterly meetings of a steering committee in Dushanbe, chaired by the Director of the National 
HIV/AIDS Center, and including representatives from the Ministry of Transport (MOT) or project 
implementation unit (PIU), the Committee on Women and Family Affairs, government agencies 
involved in anti-trafficking and regulation of migration, and relevant international organizations 
and local NGOs. At the district level, it will be responsible for organizing quarterly meetings of 
an  advisory  working  group,  chaired  by  the  Department  of  Health,  and  including  local 
government representatives, local representatives of the Committee on Women and Family 
Affairs, community leaders (jamoat7 level), the UNDP office in Garm, international organizations, 
and local NGOs. The steering committee and advisory working group will provide guidance on 
the implementation of the component. They will establish a forum for technical discussions and 
updates on ongoing government- and/or donor-funded programs, which may inform and/or 
contribute to orienting the focus of the proposed interventions.

number of HIV testing kits, STI treatment packages, and condoms distributed; (v) percentage of 
people seeking information on HIV/AIDS testing and counseling; (vi) percentage of people being 
tested for HIV; and (vii) number of STI patients seeking care and treatment.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  Project,  including  rural  roads,  by 
comparing the with- and without-project scenarios. In the without-project scenario, the road is 
assumed to receive only minimal maintenance and will continue to deteriorate. The with-project 
scenario includes routine and periodic maintenance according to international standards. The 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  considered  various  mutually  exclusive  project 
alternatives, and the proposed Project is based on the most cost effective and least cost option. 
The economic analysis covers 23 years (2007–2029), based on a 3-year implementation period. 
All benefits and costs are in constant 2005 prices. The economic prices are expressed using the 
world price numeraire. 
 
B.  Costs 
 
2.  Project  economic  costs  include  the  resource  costs  of  road  improvement  and 
maintenance (including rural roads), equipment, and consulting services. Price contingencies, 
interest  during  construction,  and  taxes  and  duties  are  excluded.  Costs  were  divided  into 
tradable and non-tradable portions. A standard conversion factor of 0.9 was applied to the non-
tradable portion. To take into account local unemployment and underemployment, costs for 
unskilled labor were adjusted by a shadow wage rate factor of 0.75 to arrive at the economic 
opportunity cost.

B.  Description of the Project  
 
2.  The proposed Project will consist of the rehabilitation of about 77 kilometers (km) of the 
center section of the Dushanbe–Kyrgyz border road (km 140 to km 217), the 12-km section 
adjacent to the border, and 60 km of rural roads in the project area. The project road passes 
through  the  rayons  (regions)  of  Nurobod,  Rasht,  and  Dzhirgatal.  The  project activities  will 
commence in 2007 and be completed by the end of June 2009. Average daily traffic on the 
section south of Garm in 2005 is 560 vehicles, which will increase to 973 vehicles in 2010 and

Kazakhstan, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), and Uzbekistan. 
 
3.  Project  activities  will  include  road  rehabilitation  (overlay,  resurfacing,  and

storage  sites.  All  construction  activities  will  occur  within  the  existing  right-of-way,  with  the 
exception of (i) minor road realignments in mountainous areas (within unutilized government-
owned land), and (ii) road widening (2–4 m) within two short sections through peri-urban areas.

is open to the south, toward Dushanbe. As it flows southwards, the Surkhob River becomes the 
Vakhsh River, which feeds several large reservoirs and a number of large hydropower plants.

D.  Gender Development  
Men and women achieved considerable social and economic gains under the FSU, but gender equality 
has been undermined since independence. Social relations have been disrupted by changes such as the 
privatization of economic assets, giving rise to new economic relations among families, communities, and 
the Government.  Access  to  resources  required  for  survival was  further limited during the civil war, with 
corresponding influence on social and gender relations. The conflicts between traditional values and 
current economic needs are mediated within families, but the conflicts between traditional values and 
gender roles are more difficult to mediate. Women are expected to uphold traditional values while 
contributing to their families’ livelihoods. Traditional gender roles and expectations of girls and women limit 
their access to education, skills, resources such as land, and frequently to knowledge of the outside world. 
Pressure on men to meet all their families’ needs is also strong, and this stress is sometimes expressed as 
domestic violence or psychological harassment. Socioeconomic and gender-relevant issues in the project 
area were considered in the project design. These include traditional rural societies; seasonal male labor 
migration  to  the  Russian  Federation;  conservative  religious  beliefs  and  associated  gender-based 
practices; a high percentage of households headed by females, including war widows; women’s lack of 
employable skills; increasing drug trafficking and consumption patterns; and women’s greater exposure to 
the risks and impact of HIV/AIDS2 and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). 
 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The lack of connectivity between national highways and rural feeder roads critically affect women’s access 
to basic social services (district health and education facilities) and district markets in areas characterized 
by traditional conservative values and related gender-based discriminatory practices. According to the 
PPTA’s social and poverty assessment, the project area is characterized by increasing gaps in women’s 
access to post-secondary education and health services. Out of 210 surveyed households, only 2% of 
women had attended vocational schools and/or colleges, compared with 17% of men. Females reported 
lower literacy. Limited access to health services has been identified as a critical factor affecting women’s 
lives, as reflected in low health indicators (with high maternal mortality rates), limited knowledge of 
sanitation, reproductive health, HIV/AIDS and other STIs. Household surveys indicated that men have a 
wide range of employment opportunities, while women are predominantly limited to agriculture (78%) and 
tending livestock (13%). The average income of women was only 60% that of men. 
 
The Project will have indirect and direct benefits for women. Indirect benefits are mostly related to 
enhanced connectivity and include increased access to education and health facilities; increased travel to 
towns; increased marketability of women’s products (fruits and vegetables); increased access to jobs (in 
local markets); and increased access to information. Women will benefit from outside ideas as access to 
the rest of the country improves. A direct benefit is the adoption of an integrated and community-based 
approach to HIV/AIDS and migration, targeting local communities and high-risk groups. It will reduce the 
level of risk within the campsites and along the corridor of influence, and establish an environment 
conducive to the maintenance of safe sexual practices among seasonal migrants, women, intravenous 
drug users, sex workers, and transport and construction operators.

resettlement consultation, implementation, and timely delivery of entitlements. 
 
E.  Vulnerable Groups 
 
10.  Among the affected households, two are headed by women. Their income of less than 
TJS500 per year is below the poverty line of TJS600. Since the Project will not affect their 
farmland or productive assets, there will be no additional support from the Government other 
than compensation. However, MOT will provide the opportunity for these households to be 
employed under the Project so that they can earn extra income. 
 
F.  Consultation and Grievance Redress 
 
11.  The Land Code of Tajikistan (2004) requires disclosure of information and consultation 
with people affected. The people affected have been notified about the key elements of the SRP 
during meetings and interviews. Prior to implementation, there will be further consultations 
arranged by the local land committees to discuss specific impacts on each household. The 
resettlement scope, expected timeframe, compensation rates for land and other assets, other 
assistance to replace assets, relocation, and the grievance redress mechanisms will also be 
explained.  The  local  land  committees  will  ensure  that  any  concerns  raised  by  the  people 
affected are quickly addressed. 
 
12.  All complaints will be processed based on Article 47, Chapter 7 of the Land Code of 
Tajikistan (2004). People affected must first submit their written complaint to the local land 
committee. If their complaint is not settled, they can file an appeal in court. 
 
G.  Monitoring and Reporting 
 
13.  Since  the  Project’s  impacts  on  households will  be  minor,  simple  monitoring  will  be 
carried out to check the process of compensation. Internal monitoring and evaluation will be 
undertaken by the project implementation unit and reported to ADB through quarterly progress 
reports. External monitoring will be done by an international and/or domestic nongovernment 
organization as part of project performance monitoring. Resettlement monitoring for this Project 
will be part of the overall social impact monitoring. An annual budget of $5,000 for 5 years is 
allocated for the social impact monitoring. 
 
H.  Finance and Implementation Schedule 
 
14.  The SRP budget estimate is $12,000 for all costs including compensation; resettlement 
subsidy; and payments for other assets such as housing, moving allowances, and fees for 
resettlement administration. The Government will guarantee to supplement the resettlement 
budget  as  necessary,  to  meet  any  shortfall  that  may  arise  during  the  achievement  of  the 
resettlement objectives. The resettlement implementation schedule has been prepared based
